en: Interview with Mark Burnette, a school psychologist with Sevier County Schools, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Burnette talks about the responsibilites in providing support to both students and faulty in the school system after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: I can remember going to the environmental center, and I went to the classroom where the little girl that passed away, and I wanted to make sure they were good and they were. The teacher had her seat still available. They were all having honest conversation about the loss, and just how to support one another. That--that was the education part that was occurring still, more so than traditional means.

Interview with Mark Burnette, a school psychologist with Sevier County Schools, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Burnette talks about the responsibilites in providing support to both students and faulty in the school system after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: I can remember going to the environmental center, and I went to the classroom where the little girl that passed away, and I wanted to make sure they were good and they were. The teacher had her seat still available. They were all having honest conversation about the loss, and just how to support one another. That--that was the education part that was occurring still, more so than traditional means.

Would you state your name and tell us a little about your background?
Tell us a little about what you do as a school psychologist for the Sevier County School System?
Can you share with us your experiences in the days and weeks leading up to the wildfire?
Can you talk about what the Fall 2016 semester was like and what concerns you had?
What part of the county were you in the day of the fire? Can you tell us about what transpired that evening for you?
Can you tell us about your experiences in the days after the wildfire and reconnecting with your colleagues to develop a plan?
Were you responsible for providing guidance to the teachers about how to interact with students?
Can you talk about how your role evolved during the weeks and months after the fire? Did you have the chance to talk to the students?
From your perspective as a psychologist, how do you find storytelling as a therapeutic process? How else did you see the traumatic experiences being processed by individuals?
What were some of the stages of trauma that you witnessed?
Concerning the disappearance of students, did you notice a large number of Hispanic students that didn't return after the wildfire?
Being four years out, are people still dealing with this trauma or have they started to move on?
What would you say the impact on the teachers and students has been as a psychologist?
You mentioned going through training to deal with this, what impact has the fire left on you?
How would you say that the fire shaped community relations?
Do you feel like people are better prepared for future disasters?
Right now we're in an ongoing economic and health disaster (COVID-19), can you talk about how it has affected your life?
Was there anything else that was surprising or good that came out of these wildfires?
Is there anything that we haven't talked about that you would like to speak on?
As a psychologist, in your experience is sharing one's story of a traumatic experience a way to heal?

seo.title: Interview with Mark Burnette, 2020-06-11 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
